subject: Re: "Bug in JUnit MoneyBag.java example?" found by Jamie Andrews
msgSnippet: ... There is no official bug report.  The posts here, and in news:comp.software.extreme-programming are the only documentation.
messageBody:
> --- Kent Beck, responding to Jeff Grigg:
>> [...] I agree with Jamie Andrews' observation. appendTo()
>> in an implementation detail. It needs to be public because
>> it is used polymorphically. It should not be part of the
>> API. One fix is to create a separate interface just for
>> that one method. Another is to add a warning to the javadoc.

--- Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> I'm not sure I understand the actual bug here. (Does anyone
> have a URL for the actual description of the bug, not just
> the newsgroup?) [...]

There is no official bug report. The posts here, and in
news:comp.software.extreme-programming are the only documentation.

http://groups-beta.google.com/group/comp.software.extreme-
programming/tree/browse_frm/thread/abb6e38f1e302b72/faf1514df7169195?

3Den%26#doc_faf1514df7169195
->
http://tinyurl.com/e2zpy


> [...] Most Java code exposes far more methods as public
> than it should. If indeed this method should not be part
> of the API, then it should not be public. [...]

Yup. But it's defined in an 'interface', so it can be used
polymorphically. Being part of an interface, it must be public.
So... One could define another interface, as Kent Beck suggested.
Or one could introduce an abstract base class as a parent to Money
and MoneyBag. Or one could pitch the double-dispatch "add" code,
and do something else. Maybe there should be a "money bag"
interface, to allow for alternate implementations of MoneyBag?

> Often overuse of public reflects a failure to use package
> protected methods, often because the application has been
> divided into packages and yet the subpackages need to be
> able to access the internal parts of the superpackages.

Yes. But Money and MoneyBag are in the same package. I think this
suggests that they should have a common base class, for 'protected'
implementation details.


Conclusion:
I suppose it could be fixed. But it's sample code, so I find it
hard to get really excited about it.
